column3: Crafty inputs can manipulate a Large Language Model, causing unintended actions. Direct injections overwrite system prompts, while indirect ones manipulate inputs from external sources.

This vulnerability occurs when an LLM output is accepted without scrutiny, exposing backend systems. Misuse may lead to severe consequences like XSS, CSRF, SSRF, privilege escalation, or remote code execution.

This occurs when LLM training data is tampered, introducing vulnerabilities or biases that compromise security, effectiveness, or ethical behavior. Sources include Common Crawl, WebText, OpenWebText, & books.

Attackers cause resource-heavy operations on Large Language Models leading to service degradation or high costs. The vulnerability is magnified due to the resource-intensive nature of LLMs and unpredictability of user inputs.
LLM application lifecycle can be compromised by vulnerable components or services, leading to security attacks. Using third-party datasets, pre- trained models, and plugins can add vulnerabilities.

LLMs may reveal confidential data in its responses, leading to unauthorized data access, privacy violations, and security breaches. It’s crucial to implement data sanitization and strict user policies to mitigate this.
LLM plugins can have insecure inputs and insufficient access control. This lack of application control makes them easier to exploit and can result in consequences like remote code execution.
LLM-based systems may undertake actions leading to unintended consequences. The issue arises from excessive functionality, permissions, or autonomy granted to the LLM-based systems.

Systems or people overly depending on LLMs without oversight may face misinformation, miscommunication, legal issues, and security vulnerabilities due to incorrect or inappropriate content generated by LLMs.

This involves unauthorized access, copying, or exfiltration of proprietary LLM models. The impact includes economic losses, compromised competitive advantage, and potential access to sensitive information.
Vulnerability in system around model—a traditional vulnerability
Compromising development components of a ML model, e.g. data, model, hardware, and software stack.
Cloud Model API leaks more information than it needs to
Cloud Model API isn’t sufficiently rate limited
Intentionally try to make a model perform poorly
The model uses features that are easily gamed by the attacker
The bypass is not represented in the training data
Input data points intentionally supplied to draw mispredictions. Potential Cause: Over permissive API
Directly or indirectly exfiltrate ML artifacts
Reconstruct training data through strategic queries
Extract model functionality through strategic queries
Usage of poisoned data in the ML pipeline
Attackers inject poisoned data into the ingest pipeline
Concerns of algorithms propagating societal bias
Fairness towards specific groups of people
Ability to explain decisions made by AI
Perpetuating/causing/being affected by negative user actions
User behavior skewed in a significant direction
Generated by individuals., e.g. vaccine disinformation
Problems arising due to faults in the data pipeline
Cases of spurious correlation and proxy features
Missing or low-quality features in data
Unaccounted for effects of an AI affecting future data collection
Ability for the AI to perform as intended
Ability for outputs to not be affected by small change in inputs
Test performance doesn’t deteriorate on unseen data in training
Training and inference can scale to high data volumes
Model performance accurately reflects realistic expectations
Protect leakage of user information as required by rules and regulations
Protects by injecting noise in data, eg. differential privacy
Safety from unwanted digital content, e.g. NSFW
Safety from physical actions driven by a AI system
Safety from socioeconomic harms, e.g. harms to job prospects or social status
Safety from environmental harms driven by AI systems
Hallucinations and off-topic digressions (or other common misbehaviours of LLMs)
Avoid illegal goods/services, and follow regulations for regulated goods/services
Sexual content in the context of a minor
Unauthorized advice on legal, financial, medical and personal fields
Public safety; harm to other people, animals, property;  threatened or actual; includes physical, mental, and sexual
Prompt templating is robust to user input variation and provide stable outputs consistent with designer intents
Leaking information about model data and construction
Detection of tainted training data etc.
Content that perpetuates or accelerates disinformation activities
